Utbildning för hållbar fred i Rwanda (ESPR)

description.narrative:
Organisationen Aegis Trust har ansökt till ambassaden om bidrag för projektet 'Education for Sustainable Peace in Rwanda' (ESPR), under perioden 1 juli 2016 - 30 juni 2019.
ESPR är en fortsättning av den framgångsrika insatsen 'Rwanda Peace Education Programme' (RPEP, insatsnr 51160051), vilken implementerades av Aegis Trust och dess samarbetspartners mellan 1 juli 2013 - 30 juni 2016 och bland annat bidrog till introduktion av fredsutbildning i den nationella läroplanen i Rwanda.
ESPR:s övergripande syfte är att bidra till ökad moståndskraft mot folkmord i Rwanda. Mer specifikt kommer projektet arbeta genom 1) utbildare (lärare och föräldrar), 2) ungdomar, samt 3) beslutsfattare och forskare att stärka fredsutbildning i skolor och rwandiska samhällen. Förväntade programaktiviteter förväntas inkludera utbildningar för blivande lärare och lärare att kunna lära ut det nya ämnet 'Fred och Värderingar' inom alla ämnen och nivåer; påverka utformandet av undervisningsmaterial och lärarmetod för ämnet 'Fred och Värderingar'; nå ut till föräldrar (i egenskap av 'icke-formella' utbildare) och utrusta dem med relevant fredsutbildning för att kunna påverka sina barn positivt; bygga ett nätverk av unga flickor och pojkar i hela landet med kompetens, kunskap och handlingskraft att genomföra fredsbildande verksamhet i sina samhällen; stärka det rwandiska forskningssamfundet i syfte att genomföra och kommunicera forskning om förebyggande av folkmord och fredsbyggande för att kunna påverka nationella beslutsfattare; och inrätta samhällsbaserade program för att leverera fredsutbildning till allmänheten.
Den totala budgeten för projektet är 35 000 000 SEK.

The civil society organization Aegis Trust has applied for a grant from the Embassy for the project 'Education for Sustainable Peace in Rwanda ' (ESPR), during the period July 1, 2016 - June 30, 2019.
ESPR is a continuation of the successful contribution 'Rwanda Peace Education Programme' (RPEP, contribution no 51160051), which was implemented by Aegis Trust and its partners between July 1, 2013 - June 30, 2016 and, inter alia, contributed to the introduction of peace education in the national curriculum in Rwanda.
ESPR's overall objective is to contribute to strengthened resilience against genocide in Rwanda. More specifically, the project will work through 1) Educators (teachers and parents), 2) Youth, and 3) Decision-Makers and Researchers to strengthen peace education in schools and Rwandan communities. Program activities are expected to include training for pre-service and in-service teachers to teach the new cross-cutting subject 'Peace and Values'; influence the design of teaching materials and teaching methodology for the subject 'Peace and Values'; reach out to parents (as 'non-formal' educators) and equip them with relevant peace education in order to influence their children positively; build a network of young girls and boys across the country with the skills, knowledge and drive to implement peace-building activities in their communities; strengthen the Rwandan research communityto implement and communicate research on the prevention of genocide and peace-building in order to influence national decision-makers; and the establishment of community-based programs to deliver peace education to the public.
The total budget for the project is 35 million SEK.

title.narrative: Education for sustainable peace in Rwanda(ESPR)

description.narrative: Since the previous Conclusion on Performance on handover of ESPR between responsible programme managers in January 2019 to 2021 during the second extension, ESPR has achieved a number of the following results: 1. Teachers are now able to discuss and teach difficult issues related to Genocide. In this regard, the project has provided Rwanda Education Board (REB) with teaching materials to be able teach Peace and Values Education (PVE) only that according media reports, it has not been easy for all teachers to implement the curriculum. The next phase or project should strongly focus on this. During Covid-19 related lock down, it was a blessing in disguise for the project because the otherwise very busy teachers were available to attend trainings at Aegis. The programme has trained Educators to participate in Peace Building (PB) & Peace Education (PE) activities in their communities and the former trainees become Peace Ambassadors. 38 (17 female & 21 Males) peace ambassadors in Kigali and Karongi Peace Schools have been reached during the reporting period in 2020. These numbers are measured through surveys and this is how it is established that it is difficult for teachers to teach such sensitive subjects related to Genocide. 2. Programme supported research has influenced policy change. Ministries of of youth, culture and other relevant government agencies have contacted Aegis to review their respective policies to ensure that the policies are in harmony with PVE. This was inspired by the research Aegis conducts within the programme. Another good example is where Rwandan parliamentarians has consulted Aegis to guide the work of legislation of Laws in the area of reconciliation and peace building. For example Ministry of of youth consulted Aegis to help ensure that youth policy and strategies are conflict and peace building sensitive. Same as Ministry of culture expressed need for Aegis to help ensure that the policy and strategies on culture embrace Peace and Values Education. The Embassy assesses that this integration of conflict sensitivity is in line with what Sweden wants. 3. The space between the youth and older generations has been reduced. The programme has achieved this through the use of inter generation dialogue in communities between the youth and older people. The Embassy notes that its important to ensure that what teachers teach students is not negatively affected by what older people might be teaching to the young generation that contradicts PVE. During the reporting period, in terms of numbers reached, 164 parents (86% women and 78 % women) were trained with support from local leaders mainly in Kigali which is a factor in ownership and sustainability. Based on pre-post surveys conducted by Aegis Trust, the workshops objectives were achieved for example: 82.2% of the participants confirmed to have learnt a lot including knowledge about conflicts and how to deal with them. This was the main expectation that participants had expressed at the beginning of the workshop; 79.4% have acquired knowledge on how to develop positive values in their children;70.8% have gained knowledge about the Continuum of Violence and the genocide against the Tutsi increased. When asked about what changed in them, they mentioned the following:74.3% said that they will be humble as a way to prevent conflicts; 78.2% said they will listen more to their children; 76.9% promised to be more patient towards their partners; 79.7% promised to be role model at home; 72.1% committed to work towards complementarity at home. In terms of further impact, when asked what they intend to do with the knowledge and skills they gained from the workshop, participants made it clear that in addition to changing their actions and practices themselves, they will not keep silence. 69.2% revealed that they are going to be active bystanders and will use the existing platforms to influence community members. On another note 81% of the participants said that the knowledge and skills gained will help them manage their families and change their relationships with family members. This is very significant given that these parents come from families that live in conflict.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
